message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the effects of radiation. Radiation can make something warmer by transferring energy to the object. When radiation is absorbed by an object, it increases the kinetic energy of its molecules, causing the object to heat up. Option (A) is incorrect because radiation does not make something cooler. Option (C) is unrelated to the effects of radiation. Option (D) is also unrelated to radiation and refers to physical hardness, not temperature.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the effects of radiation. Radiation can make something warmer. When certain types of radiation, such as infrared radiation, are absorbed by an object, they increase the object's thermal energy, causing it to warm up. Option (A) is incorrect because radiation does not generally make things cooler. Option (C) is incorrect because radiation does not affect the weight of an object. Option (D) is incorrect because radiation does not make something harder.

Option (A) is incorrect because radiation does not typically make something cooler. Option (C) is incorrect because radiation does not affect the weight of an object. Option (D) is incorrect because radiation does not make something harder.
